Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CICI: Secure and Resilient Architecture: Creating Dynamic Superfacilities the SAFE Way

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern computational science is becoming increasingly collaborative as scientists utilize remote shared facilities, including instruments, compute resources, and data repositories. Department of Energy (DOE) researchers have coined the term "superfacility" to describe an integration of two or more existing facilities using high-performance networks and data management software in order to increase scientific output. Currently, superfacilities are purpose-built manually for a specific scientific application or community, limiting their use to large projects that are long-lived. Recent advances in campus science networks (Science DMZs) and federated Infrastructure-as-a-Service, as in NSF GENI, provide the basic building blocks to enable construction of dynamic superfacilities on demand. Automating the creation of superfacilities reduces their cost but introduces new security challenges. By design, their dynamic network links bypass campus security appliances in order to maintain a friction-free network path; security for these paths is typically addressed by managing interconnections manually. This project creates a framework to automate, authorize, and monitor end-to-end connectivity across dynamic superfacilities, bringing this technology to a wider range of scientists.

The SAFE Superfacilities project brings together researchers and IT support organizations from RENCI/UNC Chapel Hill, Duke University and DOE/ESnet. The goal of this project is to generalize support for stitching dynamic network circuits by providing the authorization and security monitoring necessary to enable general, dynamic, and safe interconnections as a foundational building block for Science DMZ, Software Defined Exchanges (SDX), and superfacilities. One element of the project focuses on using the SAFE logical trust system to authorize dynamic stitching of network links in two systems developed, deployed, and operated by the researchers and their collaborators: the ExoGENI testbed and Duke's Software-Defined Science Network (SDSN) campus network exchange. A second element addresses dynamic out-of-band security monitoring of traffic over these links. The project serves as a model for improving security while maintaining high-performance friction-free network paths between campus scientists and remote facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Networked infrastructure-as-a-service (NIaaS) testbeds continue to advance.  US-funded NIaaS research testbeds include GENI, Internet2 AL2S, ESnet/SDN, the Chameleon cloud, and the future FABRIC testbed.  They enable researchers to construct and deploy experimental networks under software control.

This project developed concepts, practices, and software to deploy, manage, and interconnect virtual network service providers (NSPs) on NIaaS testbeds.   An NSP carries network traffic on behalf of customers and peer networks that attach to it and pass traffic.   The project enhanced testbed features to connect with NSPs, developed software for safe networking with testbed-hosted NSPs, and showed how to use logical trust to build flexible security policy for these NSP networks.

Virtual science networks.  NSPs can implement built-to-order virtual science networks that carry traffic between and among campuses and scientific facilities.  The project shows how to configure and program NSPs to provide useful functions and capabilities as a template for supporting the cyberinfrastructure demands of future science. They include support for custom security policy to control who can send traffic to a network endpoint, block dangerous or unwanted traffic, specify functions to inspect the traffic, and limit traffic to transit designated eligible paths.

NSP control.  A key outcome of this project is the ExoPlex controller framework for secure policy-based networking over programmable network infrastructures. An ExoPlex NSP combines a logical NSP controller with an off-the-shelf SDN controller and an existing trust logic platform (SAFE), both of which were enhanced for this project.  Additional outcomes include the deployment of ExoPlex NSPs in pilot experiments involving the Duke campus network and the ExoGENI, ESnet, and Chameleon testbeds.  They show how to deploy virtual science networks with integrated security management using software-defined networking and network function virtualization (SDN/NFV).   One exemplary NSP serves as a Software-Defined Exchange (SDX) in which customers of the NSP declare policy rules that mediate their connectivity with other customers, e.g., to block unwanted traffic, in concert with out-of-band monitoring of permitted traffic flows by provisioning NFV instances (Bro/Zeek) for intrusion prevention.  The project demonstrated how to plug software modules into NSP control software to manage various advanced network features, including adaptation of an elastic network topology to changing traffic demands,  interposed NFV instances, traffic filtering, and custom security policy.

Interdomain networking.  NSPs may interconnect to form interdomain networks that route traffic along paths spanning multiple NSPs, similar to traffic in the Internet.   The research showed how to link testbed experiments to build secure interdomain networks that can carry live production traffic safely.   Because the behaviors of the NSPs are defined by their control software (SDN), NSP controllers may communicate logical trust information through service interfaces to manage routing of traffic through the internetwork, outside the constraints of existing Internet routing protocols (e.g., BGP).  In this way the project creates a foundation to explore approaches to manage safe interdomain networking that capture the current state of the art in the Internet and extend it in certain useful ways.  

Logical network security.  The project showed how to use logical trust to declare a range of desired interdomain routing behaviors and security policies in a rigorous way without the need to change the NSP control software.   NSP controllers use cryptographically protected statements in a logic language to represent network address ownership, candidate routes, rules to validate routes, and restrictions on how to select and propagate routes among NSPs.  One outcome is to show how logical trust can capture and extend the power of state-of-the-art practices to block spoofed (inauthentic) traffic in an internetwork.  The logical approach encodes restrictions on propagating routes into logical route advertisements, and applies extended logical rules for route validation in concert with a standard technique to block non-compliant traffic called unicast reverse path forwarding.

Campus infrastructure and deployment.  This project influenced academic scientific research networking at Duke University and in the Research Triangle region more generally.   Duke's IT staff explored advanced features for a campus network to enable safe interconnection of circuit-based science networks into the campus.  Personnel from RENCI/UNC Chapel Hill, Duke University, and DOE/ESnet worked collaboratively to develop approaches to manage secure virtual science networks across regional and national science networks.  Duke deployed intrusion monitoring using Bro/Zeek in its campus Software-Defined Science Network (SDSN), following the friction-free out-of-band model of the testbed-hosted pilot, together with features to load-balance traffic across multiple Zeek instances, leverage Docker to develop and test custom Zeek scripts, and correlate Zeek events with other security events across Duke's network.  The work from this award is a foundation to enhance connectivity and security in support of diverse research use cases, and will be leveraged for Duke's advanced SDN network.
